item.title: How to use timers?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

This is moparscape related, but what the hell.

The server loops through all of the clients every 500 ms, or so. During this, it calls a method called ‘process’ in each of the players to handle the incoming packets (but not to actually read them for the login thread does that.) Basically, if you increment a variable every time the process() method is called, you can count that has a half a second. If the number equals 120, then you have around one minute that has passed since it first started incrementing. Understand?

Read full topic

item.title: How to use timers?
item.dc:creator: @supamagier supamagier
item.description:
@supamagier wrote:

I’m not really sure, look, I saw this as a reply on how to make pots work in mopar:

[quote=“ZTR Zac, post:2, topic:183001”]Ok basically first off you would need to create a timer. And you would also want to make a boolean to say if your using str pot or not

public int strTimer = 0; public boolean usingStrPot = false;

paste that into where your booleans are

k now you need to create the actual code to make the strength go down after some time

[code]if (usingStrPot == true && strTimer = 0) {
if (playerLevel[2] > getLevelForXP(playerXP[2]) {
playerLevel[2] = (playerLevel[2] - 1);
strTimer = 70;
} else {
usingStrPot == false;
}
}

[/code]

Ok, that basically means “if the players using a strength pot and his strength is over the level he should have for the amount of exp he has then the players new strength level is his current strength level - 1(decreasing strength level slowly).” It then sets the timer back to 70 so it has to count down again and do the same code when timer = 0

Now, we need to make the str pot actually initialize that code when its drunk.

case 113: usingStrPot = true; strTimer = 70; abc = getLevelForXP(playerXP[2]); cba = abc / 10; aaa = cba / 2; abc2 = aaa + cba; if (abc2 <= 1) { abc2 = 2; } playerLevel[2] = getLevelForXP(playerXP[2]); playerLevel[2] += abc2; sendFrame126(""+playerLevel[2]+"", 4006); deleteItem(113, GetItemSlot(113), 1); addItem(115, 1); updateRequired = true; appearanceUpdateRequired = true; GoOn = false; break;

That initializes the code and starts the timer and increases your strength.
Paste that below any of the cases in your client.java
Hope it helps.[/quote]

See where I’m going? He creates a timer, but I nowhere see a start method or whatsoever to make it run/stop. Like it’s just automaticly count down when created/changed. :\ Explain please.

Read full topic

item.title: How to use timers?
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

im assuming you meant something like this?

[code]class Timer {
long start, finish;

public Timer(int wait) {
     start = System.currentTimeMillis();
     finish = start +wait;
}

boolean isUp() {
    return (System.currentTimeMillis() >= finish);
}

long getStart() {
    return start;
}

long getFinish() {
    return finish;
}

long timeTaken() {
    return (System.currentTimeMillis() - start);
}

}[/code]

Read full topic
